comments.commentBody:
“I got a triple-double. Who can say they got a triple-double? I’m not really worried about it.”
Yo JaVale there is no 'I' in team; last I checked hoops is a team game. You playin' for the Wizards or you playin' for JaVale?

Last foul of game- absolutely ridiculous call. Mack's foul with 1.4 secs actually impacted the possibility of a shot at the basket for Pitt, however unlikely that he would score. The very aggressive foul knocked Brown out of bounds. The final foul by Robinson had no possible impact on the game other than to allow the referee to move Butler 80 feet closer to the basket. What's equally disturbing is the way Mack trash-talked at Brown, standing in front of him on the foul line, while the oblivious refs both watched replays to determine how to reset the time clock. You expect that gamesmanship in the NBA, not in college tournament play. In the former it could be a technical foul. In NCAA it most certainly is. But more importantly, it points out how the on-air analysis of these games often softens its criticism in order to validate the outcome.

Great game!
A few mistakes, but the team looked like a very solid group of guys that really were in synch tonight!!
Wow, Agudelo put on a performance tonight!
Addition by subtraction

What a great comeback!!!
We love you Charlie!!!
See you with the Nat'l Team soon!!
Two fouls, both dumb and both deserving of being called. In some cosmic way they canceled each other out.
So far no responses.  I now have three of these chick-a-dees and am waitig for the W.C. Fields clue.

@Dutch--You mean, too hard for you.  Don't give up.  What's unenjoyable for you now might become really enjoyable for you later, when you're ready for harder puzzles.  Harder than the average Sunday puzzle, in my opinion, but hardly bad fill, and not unenjoyable at all.  And as far as the trickery goes, the more, the better.
As someone who wishes she could attend, I appreciate Deb's attention to describing the atmosphere at ACPT. Thanks very much for keeping us vicarious attenders in the loop!
ONE WORD: arbitrary must be defeated for gerneral civilians, anywhere.

In case you wonder what would make Libya any worse than Bahrain, Yemen, &c:
Remember Lockerbie?
He paid restitution and said things were different now - and now he turns on his own people. Help them lock him up.

March 19, 2011

The world wants Qaddafi’s out, now!!!!!!!

Libya must be allowed to have a new start, and new governance and social development.

He’s has shown the world how awful, cruel, and uncompromising a tyrant can behavior, as well, not with impunity on earth.

Where he goes now, and how long it takes to collar him; he’s given just cause by international attention for humanitarian relief to his democratic protestors.

The mad dog has no cards other than death, or The Hague trial court.

The lessons is don’t play on the world stage and think your actions are going to go unnoticed and devoid of consequences. In words of President Obama there will be consequences for his actions, and killing civilians. Mohammed was in the spiritual realm of truth and Qaddafi has no soul. Right behavior is according to early holy writ as ever revealed and shared with majesty of wisdom’s liberty.

It may take a week, or a year or several, but he is marked and so are his world wide funds should want to play with hired thugs or any other the money trail will be followed......

Joseph Amato
Manhattan, N. Y.

The worst thing about this situation is not that the U.S. is involved. It is rather that, as the article says, the U.S. considers the effort to be, "Under French and British leadership."

It is the French, the Brits, and the Italians who want to get their hands on Libya's oil. "Our" (the U.S.'s) oil is in Iraq and Iran; the Europeans consider Libya's to be "their" oil.

If the effort turns out badly for Libyans, that will almost certainly be because America stood aside and let European nations expropriate Libya's most valuable resource.

gadafi regime is autocratic and insane to commit airplane bombarded of more than two decades ago to kill two hundreds of innocent passengers, and the mad should be punished long term inmprisonment by international court.but,what US adopted double dimensions to deal with tyrants in the world is unacceptable to the common people. as an universal principle, human rights, democracy and freedom, which comprise the US fundamental basis, is still too hard to get for common people in wide range of world, because multinational bourgeoises collude with corrupted cadres  to make profits in spite of bad condition of human rights in host country where free speech had been banned, innocent individual was often persecuted by corrupted cadres, and people lost the basical housing rights. so, the west allies to strike libya is possible to recognised by people in the world. to change this situation of prople against US led coalition to take operation in the world, only way is to accept unique standard and action to dictators, authoritarism in the world, to really help the common people to fulfill real democracy and freedom.

What a difference a day makes! If we had struck just 24 hours earlier, we could have hit the tanks on their way to Benghazi and kept Qaddafi's forces out of that city. Now, Bengahzi will be a battlefield, much of it will be destroyed, there will be many refugees, and the rebels will have no credible center of power and government.

The only way to "win" quickly now is to make things so unpleasant for Qaddafi's forces that many of them will turn and support the rebels. That will take a clever combination of diplomacy and "shock and awe," with maximum damage to military hardware and minimum civilian casualties. If that tactic fails, there will be a long conflict, and everything will depend upon the rebels' perseverance and how they are armed.

All this might have been avoided by quicker military intervention. I supported that intervention and was impressed by the speed of our diplomatic action, which produced a strong and decisive UN green light in record time. But the action didn't follow quickly enough, and there aren't enough Arab participants, despite the fact that all his neighbors, like us, see Qaddafi as a mad dog.

It's a messy situation, much messier than it had to be. And it makes me want to add another condition to the Powell Doctrine. Military intervention must not only involve clear goals, overwhelming force, and a clear exit strategy. It must also be timely.

That said, the poor timing put our President and his foreign counterparts in a terrible dilemma. They could either do nothing and appear totally feckless and inept, or they could make this belated strike and try to pull victory out of the jaws of defeat. Unfortunately, we have seen too many Hobson's choices like that lately, and they have not always ended happily.

Why can't one of these elite highly trained secret government agents from one of the allied countries simply get in there and take him out.  I mean bang, bang take him out.  It will save a lot of innocent lives.  Not like they haven't assassinated people before.  Ghadaffi is evil, brutal and runs the whole show.
I am not so sure the Libyan rebels want Democracy... What I do know is that they want freedom of oppression. Those two terms can be mutually exclusive.

The good news: finally, someone else besides the U.S. steps up; the bad news it took two weeks of dithering to do it ; let us hope it is not too late to avert Gaddafi regaining the momentum and that it won't be necessary to send a quarter million or more troops into Libya to clean up the mess; in case anyone is counting, we don't have a quarter million men and women to spare and it is not likely the French and Brits will want to step in to fill the gap.
Here we go again....
Wow, Obama is a tough guy outside the US while the banks and corporations bankrupt our middle class. Bravo Mr Obama.

Starting this phase of the expanding wars of the global Empire will be justified by all the FOEs (friends of Empire) both before and after the fact.

The 'fix' is in, and the theater begun with Obama pretending to be at all reluctant to leave the center of the stage for this war, which reminds me of the old 'show' of James Brown being reluctant to leave the stage, then throwing off his cape and breaking away from his handlers to come back and keep on singing.

This whole 'show', under the supposed cover of 'humanitarianism' is a monstrous scam to expand a known plan that already exists, and which everyone should read about:

This whole plan is based on Tom Barnett's 2004 explosive and heavily studied (by the CIA/MIC) book "The Pentagon's New Map" --- in which the entire swath of countries he calls the "GAP" are to be absorbed into the "OLD CORE" (which is the Western empire), and to be prevented from falling under the influence of the "NEW CORE" (easy to guess -- BRIC).

The geo-strategic plan is an up-dated version of the 1990's PNAC plan that precipitated the Iraq and Afpak wars --- but now expanding to include N. Africa, all Middle East, and South Central Asia.

This is a MUCH bigger and more carefully planned global war map for the current global Empire (politely called the "CORE") to engage in during the 2011 to 2020 time-frame.

Anyone who does not include in their research and analysis Barnett's "The Pentagon's New Map" is woefully underestimating the breadth, depth, and scope of this plan to expand from Iraq and Afpak wars to the full "GAP" (from Tunisia through Libya, Egypt, the whole Middle East, and all the way to the Chinese and Indian boarders).

As Cheney was infamous for saying, this is "BIG TIME" for the global Empire --- and must be stopped before it precipitates WWIII.

Alan MacDonald
Sanford, Maine
Liberty over violent empire -- People's Party
